instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00875: What is 820-00875? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.D6905: What is D6905? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input on very old Macbooks(before 2011), can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.ISL9239: What is ISL9239? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2016-2018 responsible for charging the battery and creating the power rail PPBUS_G3H.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
I have this new 2016 machine(non-touchbar version) that had no liquid damage at all but won't turn on at all.

I haven't worked on these models but I did check out some of Louis' videos on this model.
I am only getting around 5v on <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XA_VBUS</SIGNAL>. I believe Louis said if you only get 5v you need to check <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>. I don't get any voltage on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> and there is no short on that line.
I get 0v on <RESISTOR>R3000</RESISTOR>/01 but I was getting 3.3v on <CAPACITOR>C3208</CAPACITOR>/3108 depending on which port the charger was plugged in.

F3000/3010 are working correctly and <RESISTOR>R5320</RESISTOR>/21/22 all measured the correct resistance.
0v on L5001/<CAPACITOR>C5001</CAPACITOR>.

Also, I am using a genuine apple charger.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: Take it to Apple if you are in the EU and machine is <2 years old!!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
I'm in the US but would the same apply so I can give this back to the customer and let him know?

If not, is there anything else I could do to fix this myself?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: Nope only 1 year is US. Check voltages around <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>, <DIODE>D6901</DIODE>, <RESISTOR>R6991</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R6991</RESISTOR> had 0v on both sides and had the correct resistance. You said <DIODE>D6901</DIODE> but that doesnt exist so I think you meant <DIODE>D6905</DIODE>.
<DIODE>D6905</DIODE> had 5.2v on pins 2/3 and 0v on pin 1

I get 5v on Pin 2 of <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> and 0v on the enable Pin 2

Should I try replacing the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> chip?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: Yeah <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is a good suspect at this point.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Okay I replaced the <CHIP>ISL9239</CHIP> <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> chip and now the board turns on and works fine.

Thanks for the help duke!

[url]https://store.rossmanngroup.com/index.php/x5-<CHIP>ISL9239</CHIP>.html[/url]
